questions.question:
\( A = \{ 0,1,2,3,\dots \} \) is the set of non-negative integers. Let \( {F} \) be the set of functions from \( A \) to itself. For any two functions, \( f_1, f_2 \in {F} \), we define

\( (f_1 \odot f_2)(n) = f_1(n) + f_2(n)\)

for every number \( n \) in \( A \). Which of the following is/are CORRECT about the mathematical structure \( ({F}, \odot ) \)?

(GATE CSE 2025 SET-1)
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let \( Z_n \) be the group of integers \( \{0,1,2, \ldots, n-1\} \) with addition modulo \( n \) as the group operation. The number of elements in the group \( Z_2 \times Z_3 \times Z_4 \) that are their own inverses is

(GATE CSE 2024 SET-2)

questions.question:
Consider the operators \( \diamond \) and \( \square \) defined by \( a \diamond b=a+2 b, a \square b=a b \), for positive integers. Which of the following statements is/are TRUE?

(GATE CSE 2024 SET-1)
options:
C.

Operator \( \diamond \) over the operator \( \square \) obeys the distributive law

D.

Operator \( \square \) over the operator \( \diamond \) obeys the distributive law
correct_answer:
D.

Operator \( \square \) over the operator \( \diamond \) obeys the distributive law
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following statements is/are TRUE for a group \(G\)?

(GATE CSE 2022)
options:
A.

If for all \(x,y \in G, (xy)^2=x^2y^2\), then \(G\) is commutative.

B.

If for all \(x \in G, x^2=1\), then \(G\) is commutative. Here, 1 is the identity element of \(G\).

C.

If the order of \(G\) is 2 , then \(G\) is commutative.

D.

If \(G\) is commutative, then a subgroup of \(G\) need not be commutative.
correct_answer:
A.

If for all \(x,y \in G, (xy)^2=x^2y^2\), then \(G\) is commutative.

B.

If for all \(x \in G, x^2=1\), then \(G\) is commutative. Here, 1 is the identity element of \(G\).

C.

If the order of \(G\) is 2 , then \(G\) is commutative.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Let G be a group of order 6, and H be a subgroup of G such that 1 < |H| < 6. Which one of the following options is correct?

(GATE CSE 2021 SET-1)
options:
A.

Both G and H are always cyclic.

B.

G may not be cyclic, but H is always cyclic.

C.

G is always cyclic, but H may not be cyclic.

D.

Both G and H may not be cyclic.
questions.correct_answer:
B.

G may not be cyclic, but H is always cyclic.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following is true?

(GATE CSE 2002)
options:
A.

The set of all rational negative numbers forms a group under multiplication.

B.

The set of all non-singular matrices forms a group under multiplication.

C.

The set of all matrices forms a group under multiplication.

B.

The set of all non-singular matrices forms a group under multiplication.

questions.question:
Which one of the following is false?

(GATE CSE 1996)
options:
A.

The set of all bijective functions on a finite set forms a group under function composition.

B.

The set \(\{1, 2, \dots p-1\}\) forms a group under multiplication mod p, where p is a prime number.

C.

The set of all strings over a finite alphabet forms a group under concatenation.

D.

A subset \(S \neq \emptyset\) of G is a subgroup of the group \(\langle G, * \rangle\) if and only if for any pair of elements \(a, b \in S, a * b^{-1} \in S\).
questions.correct_answer:
C.

The set of all strings over a finite alphabet forms a group under concatenation.
questions.explanation: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

questions.question:
Which of the following statements is FALSE?

(GATE CSE 1996)
options:
A.

The set of rational numbers is an abelian group under addition

B.

The set of integers in an abelian group under addition

C.

The set of rational numbers form an abelian group under multiplication

D.

The set of real numbers excluding zero is an abelian group under multiplication
questions.correct_answer:
C.

The set of rational numbers form an abelian group under multiplication

questions.question:
Let A be the set of all non-singular matrices over real number and let * be the matrix multiplication operation. Then

(GATE CSE 1995)
options:
A.

A is closed under * but \(\langle A, *\rangle\) is not a semigroup.

B.

\(\langle A, *\rangle\) is a semigroup but not a monoid.

C.

\(\langle A, *\rangle\) is a monoid but not a group.

D.

\(\langle A, *\rangle\) is a a group but not an abelian group.
questions.correct_answer:
D.

\(\langle A, *\rangle\) is a a group but not an abelian group.
